pain_points_original.title: Securing PROTECTED Government Data
pain_points_original.description: AGS handles highly sensitive government data, creating a massive risk of breaches. The problem is ensuring any AI solution meets non-negotiable security standards, including being "independently certified through IRAP process at PROTECTED level" and ensuring data is stored within Australia.

pain_points_original.title: Low Productivity in Core Legal Tasks
pain_points_original.description: With approximately 570 lawyers, manual legal work like summarisation and discovery creates a significant productivity bottleneck. This problem limits capacity across 40 areas of law. AGS needs AI to automate these tasks, freeing up lawyers for high-value strategic work.

pain_points_original.title: Navigating Complex Legal & AI Ethics
pain_points_original.description: As a government entity, AGS must comply with strict Australian laws (e.g., Privacy Act 1988). The problem is the risk of using AI that is not "ethical, responsible, transparent and explainable". Failure to manage this could lead to significant legal and reputational damage for the government.

pain_points_original.title: Integrating AI into Existing Tech Stack
pain_points_original.description: AGS has an established tech ecosystem (iManage Cloud, Elite 3E). The problem is that a standalone AI tool would create disruptive data silos and inefficient workflows. A solution must integrate with their core software to ensure seamless adoption and enhance existing processes for their 800 staff.

pain_points_original.title: Scaling Solutions for a Large National Team
pain_points_original.description: AGS is a large national provider with 800 staff. The problem is finding an AI solution that can perform reliably for their entire workforce, with a specific requirement to support "up to 1,000 concurrent internal users". A tool that cannot scale would be a failed investment and limit firm-wide impact.

pain_points_original.title: Lack of Australian-Specific AI Tools
pain_points_original.description: The Australian legal system is unique. The problem is that generic international AI tools may lack the nuance and accuracy required. AGS is explicitly seeking tools "specifically designed to support Australian legal practices" to ensure the outputs are relevant and trustworthy for government legal work.

pain_points_original.title: Difficulty Finding Internal Knowledge
pain_points_original.description: As a large firm, AGS possesses vast internal knowledge, but locating relevant information is inefficient. The problem is this wasted time hinders lawyers' ability to leverage valuable internal precedents. They require "Smart search" to improve findability and turn their existing data into an advantage.

pain_points_original.title: Falling Behind on Advanced AI Capabilities
pain_points_original.description: The AI landscape is evolving quickly. The problem for AGS is the strategic risk of technological stagnation if they only adopt basic generative AI. Their specific interest in "emerging agentic AI systems" demonstrates a need to future-proof their operations and maintain a technological edge.

pain_points_original.title: Secure and Seamless User Access Management
pain_points_original.description: Managing system access for over 800 staff is a major operational and security burden. The problem is the inefficiency and risk of standalone user credentials. They need a solution that integrates with AGD's central "Microsoft Entra ID" to ensure secure, role-based, and easily managed access.
